nodes.text: Degree of incumbency advantage and institutional flexibility determine dynamic selection and persistence of governments; greater democracy increases adaptability to change though not always static performance
Perfect democracy (no incumbency advantage) yields emergence of the most competent government as the unique stable outcome
Any deviation from perfect democracy (some incumbency advantage) can allow multiple stable governments and enable very incompetent governments to persist
Increasing democracy beyond a baseline can sometimes lead to worse long-run governments in nonstochastic environments due to strategic blocking by incumbents
In the presence of stochastic shocks, greater democracy increases the probability that high-competence governments will come to power, enhancing adaptability

Under shocks, regimes with irreplaceable leaders (royalty-like) can sometimes outperform junta-like regimes because concentrated authority may enable adaptation when collective incumbents block reform

Method: dynamic discrete-time game model where governments are coalitions of size k, competence maps to collective utility, individuals obtain rents from office, and changes require votes and incumbent consent; equilibria analyzed under deterministic and stochastic shocks
